title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenue. The service industry is the largest sector, followed by construction and other industries. The service industry, construction, and retail trade were the largest sectors in terms of businesses and receipts. Businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives saw significant growth in both numbers and gross receipts compared to all businesses. The number of businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives grew significantly from 1992 to 1997, with their gross receipts also showing substantial growth. The Small Business Development Center program proved to be cost-effective, generating additional tax revenues that were six times the program's cost to the Federal Government in 1998. The Small Business Development Center program proved cost-effective as clients generated additional tax revenues of $468,000,000 in 1998, six times the program's cost to the Federal Government. Small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians receiving services under the program had a higher survival rate than those not receiving such services. Increased assistance through counseling under the Small Business Development Center program benefits small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians by improving their survival rates. Business counseling is crucial on Indian lands where similar services are scarce and expensive. Increased business counseling and technical assistance are crucial on Indian lands where services are scarce and expensive. Assistance through counseling has been shown to reduce default rates for Small Business Administration lending programs. The purposes of this Act are to stimulate economies and foster economic development on Indian lands, as well as assist in creating new small businesses. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands, foster economic development, assist in creating new small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, and provide management assistance. It also seeks advice from local Tribal Councils. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands, foster economic development, create new small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, and provide management assistance. It also seeks advice from local Tribal Councils and ensures full access to business counseling and technical assistance for Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Small Business Development Center assistance is provided to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Small Business Act is amended to provide an additional grant for Small Business Development Centers in eligible states to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians with business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The Business Development Center can apply for an extra grant to support small business startups and expansions owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians on Indian lands in eligible states with outreach and development services. Eligible states must have a population of these groups comprising at least 1. The Business Development Center can apply for a grant to support small business startups and expansions owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians in eligible states with a population of these groups comprising at least 1 percent. Applicants must submit a grant application in the required form to the Administration. The Business Development Center can apply for a grant to support small business startups and expansions owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians in eligible states with a population of these groups comprising at least 1 percent. Applicants must submit a grant application with required information to the Administration. The grant application must include details about the applicant's goals, the ability to provide training to indigenous groups, the proposed location of the Small Business Development Center site, and the amount of grant required. The grant application must include details about the representative number of indigenous group members, the proposed location of the Small Business Development Center site, the required grant funding, and consultation with local Tribal Councils. The grant application must include the required grant funding and consultation with local Tribal Councils. Applicants must comply with all requirements of the section, except for matching funds requirements. No applicant may receive grants exceeding a maximum amount. An applicant for a grant must comply with all requirements of the section, excluding matching funds requirements. The maximum amount of grants a single applicant can receive is $300,000 per fiscal year. Regulations must be followed after consultation with the recognized Association. The Administration will issue final regulations within 180 days to establish standards for educational, technical, and support services provided by Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance, as well as standards for work plans. The Administration will establish standards for services and work plans of Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance. The Administration may require Small Business Development Centers to develop definitions for Indian lands as per specified regulations. The term 'Indian lands' is defined as Indian country, Indian reservation, and reservation as per specific regulations. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group of Indians located in the contiguous United States, and the Metlakatla Indian Community, recognized as eligible for services provided by the Secretary of the Interior. The term 'Indian tribe member' refers to a member of an Indian tribe, excluding Alaska Natives. The term 'Alaska Native' refers to individuals defined in the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act as 'Native', while 'Native Hawaiian' refers to U.S. citizens meeting specific criteria. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to U.S. citizens who are descendants of the aboriginal people of Hawaii before 1778. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to U.S. citizens who are descendants of the aboriginal people of Hawaii before 1778. Tribal organization is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The term 'tribal organization' is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. $7,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2006 through 2008 for this purpose. Funding limitations apply. Authorization of $7,000,000 for each fiscal year 2006 through 2008 is provided for tribal organizations under U.S.C. 450b(l). Funding limitations apply, in addition to specified program limitations. Funding under this paragraph is in addition to program limitations. The Administration can only use funds appropriated in advance for this purpose. Section 21(c) of the Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers to consult with tribal organizations for advice on assisting Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.
